seed: I get a tight chest before meetings and I avoid speaking, then I regret it all day.

transcript.content: I get a tight chest before meetings and I avoid speaking, then I regret it all day.
It sounds like you feel **anxiety** when you think about meetings.  Do you find yourself thinking that avoiding speaking will make the anxiety go away?
Yeah, I guess I think if I just stay quiet, it’ll be less painful somehow. But it just leaves me feeling more frustrated and stuck afterward.

It sounds like you're thinking that staying quiet will make things less painful.  

What makes you think that being quiet will actually lessen the pain?
I don’t know, maybe because it feels safer in the moment, like I can just blend in and not draw any attention to myself. But then I’m left feeling like I missed out on something important.

It sounds like when you feel unsafe, you think about blending in.  

Do you ever wonder if there might be other ways to feel safe besides trying to disappear?
I mean, sometimes I do think about it, but it's hard to imagine what that would look like. Right now, blending in feels like the only option, even if it makes me feel more alone.

It sounds like you're saying  "blending in feels like the only option". 

What other options might there be besides blending in?
I guess there could be speaking up or even just sharing a bit of what I'm really feeling, but that seems so scary. I often worry about how people will react, and it stops me cold.

It sounds like when you think about  **sharing feelings**, you get worried about how others might react. 

What makes you think people would react in a way that feels **scary**?
I just keep replaying past experiences where I felt dismissed or judged, and it makes me think that’s how it’ll always go. It’s like a record stuck on a loop in my head.

It sounds like you're feeling stuck with the thought "that's how it'll always go,"  which is based on past experiences where you felt dismissed or judged. 

When you find yourself thinking this way, what other possibilities come to mind?
Honestly, I can’t really see any other possibilities when I'm caught in that loop. It just feels like my thoughts are on autopilot, and all I can think is that it’ll always end badly.
It sounds like you feel stuck in a pattern of thinking where "it'll always end badly."  Can you tell me more about what kinds of situations make you feel this way?
It usually happens in group settings, like at work or social gatherings. I just freeze up thinking no one will care what I have to say, and it spirals from there.

It sounds like when you're in a  **group setting**, like at work or social gatherings, you feel like **no one will care what you have to say**. 

Is there another way you might look at that thought?
I wish I could see it differently, but it just feels like I’ll be ignored or dismissed. That thought makes my stomach churn every time I think about speaking up.
It sounds like when you think about speaking up, you worry that people won't listen to you.  Is there a specific situation where this thought comes up most strongly?
Yeah, it really hits me hard in team meetings. Everyone seems so confident, and I just can't shake that feeling like my voice doesn’t matter among all the noise.
It sounds like you feel like your voice doesn't matter when you're in team meetings with everyone else seeming so confident.  When you think about it, is there any evidence to support that idea?
I mean, I can't point to anything specific, but the way people react when I do speak up just sticks with me. A lot of times, it feels like my words just fade into the background.

cbt_context.patient_text: I get a tight chest before meetings and I avoid speaking, then I regret it all day.

concepts.term: Social phobia, fear of public speaking (disorder)
